title: SSS Soraka, Supports, and Sustain
body:
They are a few champions with the ability to sustain ally champions such as; Nami's Ebb and Flow, Sona's Aria of Perseverance, Alistar's Triumphant Roar, and of course Soraka's Astral Blessing.

Each heal works in a different way;

{{champion:267}} **Ebb and Flow**'s power is divided into three parts, either **Heal-Damage-Heal** or **Damage-Heal-Damage**. In order to get your budget's worth of power you gotta position to get either two allies and one enemy, or two enemies and one ally

{{champion:37}} **Aria of Perseverance**'s power budget is mostly hidden in the resistances it grants a whole team, but in lane is used to heal *very small* amounts of health over a period of time. It's spammable and mana-hungry, yet doesn't outright erase damage.

{{champion:12}} **Triumphant Roar** heals everyone and their grandmother in the nearby area. It doesn't have much power alone and most of it goes to Ali himself, but it does heal minions, helping with pushing and denying some CS early game if you're lucky/smart.

{{champion:16}} **Astral Blessing** is a single target high-yield heal with a temporary armor buff. It's current power is offset by **HIGH** cooldowns and manacost

**(Note that Sona's and Soraka's abilities are gated(cooldown and mana), where as Nami's and Alistar's abilities are power-conditional(Can't just use on an ally to get your powerbudget's worth). I feel like this is an important distinction to keep in mind)**

Good deal, right? So what's wrong with Soraka's heal? Sure it's bursty but it only targets one ally and costs a boatload of mana.

Well, a couple of major points wrong with it. First off is that Soraka's core fantasy (Medic!) forces most of her power budget into her W and Ult, making the other abilities sorta lackluster on their own. This leads into another major issue, the optimal play style of Soraka in lane; PASSIVENESS.

Now I'm not denying the power of stacking AoE MR shred, it kills in teamfights, but in lane you really can't use it without; putting yourself up front and in serious risk (damn girl you is the squish), pushing the lane no matter what, and inadvertently denying your own carry some CS. Her Infuse can be a nice harass tool in lane if leveled first, but most Sorakas are going to opt for heal first. Thus it's main use during laning is simply to interrupt and prevent action.

With all this in mind, that means the optimal way to play Soraka during the laning phase is **super-passive-topoff-stayaway-farmfest-funtime!** This is extremely frustrating for everyone else involved. It's a decreased chance for plays to happen and for lane opponents to meaningfully interact. Sure the other supports I mentioned could do this to some extent, but their power lies in the entirety of their kits; Nami for unbelievable kiting, Alistar for CC/Displacement, Sona for insane pokes and teamwide engagement through ER.

The kit needs to be brought in line to work *with* and not *against* the structure of the game **without ruining the core fantasy of medic.** If a lot of power needs to go into Astral Blessing to fit the fantasy, then it must either be heavily gated (as is now), or power-conditional.

You can't really make a dedicated heal spell interactive, so it needs to go through another part of her kit in someway, a part of her kit that DOES provide interaction. An example below;

**DISCLAIMER:** Numbers and effects below are pure conjecture and may need changing in order to be considered balance.

| Ability | Name | Effect |
|-
|(Passive) http://i.imgur.com/2EA0naM.png | Salvation | Offensive abilities weakens the resolve of their targets, reducing their damage output by 5/10/15% for 2 seconds. Any damage applied with weakened resolve blesses the ally champion hit with Astral Essence|
|(Q) http://i.imgur.com/CJ8Qq6Q.png | Starcall | Calls down an astral being to the target area dealing 60/95/130/165/200 *(+50% Ability Power)*  magic damage.|
|(W) http://i.imgur.com/ALvytBW.png | Astral Blessing | Heals a single ally  for 65/95/125/155/185 (+ 30% AP) and increases their armor by 50/65/80/95/110 *(+15% Ability Power)*. **If the target ally is blessed with Astral Essence, the blessing is consumed and the amount healed is doubled.**|
|(E) http://i.imgur.com/6ADYApR.png | Infuse | On Ally Cast: Soraka drains 5% of her maximum mana to restore 20/40/60/80/100*(+5% maximum mana)* mana to her target ally. **If the target ally is blessed with Astral Essence, the blessing is consumed and the amount restored is doubled.** On Enemy Cast: Soraka silences the target for 1.5/1.75/2/2.25/2.5 seconds and deals 40/70/100/130/160*(+ 40% AP)(+5% maximum mana)* magic damage to them.|

With the iteration above the heal shouldn't be gated so heavily as it's pretty lackluster to cast individually. It's as strong as a single bounce of Ebb and Flow. Instead it's now power-conditional; using Starcall or Infuse offensively allows you to supe up your heal/manasustain giving you incentive to be interactive in lane. The kit also flows together better and hopefully allows for more interesting plays. Cooldowns would still have to be worked out.

Or I could be completely out of my head and this whole post is ridiculous...

replies.body:
This is a really really well done analysis. Like seriously. It's true that a dedicated heal spell cannot really be interactive. However, maybe there is some cool space to make a heal that is somehow enemy-interactive. Nami's does this to some degree, and I tend to think it's one of the better designed heals in our game.

I actually think your older idea for her passive had a better direction. Damage reduction feels really shitty for everyone involved and is incredibly powerful for how unappreciated it is. 

In general we want to create interactive gameplay *patterns*. It's acceptable for a single spell to have little to no interaction provided it is a part of an interactive pattern. Currently Soraka's W is not this. 

I'm working on a couple of different pattern directions currently and have tried a few others that have failed. 

Your goals for starcall being important to the overall pattern are good, but also remember that starcall by itself has low overall gameplay/counterplay. There might be something cool we can add to the rest of the pattern that makes a simple heal an integral part of interacting with enemies. Gonna test some stuff today and if any of it shapes up to be promising I'll share some of the results!

I'm curious where you stand on her R - Wish. Her Q and W offer little in terms of interaction, but truth be told her R does not either and probably even less than her other abilities. Yet it is an awesome, rewarding ability with many strategic uses.

I recall Riot stating somewhere that Wish is in a good place because it generally requires map awareness, and due to it's high cooldown is used more in clutch situations where a teammate is about to die. It really highlights the Save-A-Teammate feel you should enjoy when playing a healer.
Wish is a great spell. Wouldn't change it unless it was getting some new interaction, but in general it's already awesome.

Here's an idea. Have her heal give allies a shield for  x value that lasts y seconds. If the shield isn't broken in y seconds the champ is healed for the x amount. If played correctly you can go in with the shield and back out in time to still get healed and the enemy has a chance to prevent the heal. Win win

Edit2: for more counter play maybe they take damage if the shield is destroyed but heals for more if not. For example gives 100 HP shield if shield is broken take 50 damage if shield isn't broken heals for 200.

Edit: this was an idea for her W not so much for wish
whats the point of turning a shield into a heal? isn't that the same as healing in the first place?
It gives it counter play. If the enemy can break the shield you wont get healed.
Again, what exactly keeps you from casting the shield on your ally while you're both far away from the enemy?

Doesn't this further incentivize using the spell as a sustain spell, since there's less chance of the shield breaking if you use it that way?  In order to make the sustain use case less appealing, X needs to be set lower than what you would get with a regular heal (since your maximum possible swing is 2X), but if you do that, you weaken her ability to do a clutch save on an ally who's being burst down, since you can only mitigate X of a burst.

Personally, what I'd like to see is have Astral Blessing grant a shield, lifesteal, and spell vamp (possibly only granting the latter two on damage dealt to champions; alternatively, she could grant healing amplification a la Spirit Visage).  Because there's no direct healing, the shield strength can be high, maintaining her ability to do clutch saves on a focused ally.  The lifesteal/spell vamp means that it can function effectively as a heal, but only if the target is interacting with the enemy.  It also introduces counterplay: If you see the shield placed on your target, you switch from applying damage to applying CC, in order to prevent the target from taking advantage of the healing effect.

Incidentally, I am very much not a fan of the %max mana effect on Infuse; I don't think I've ever seen a Soraka build a substantial amount of mana to take advantage of this, at which point it seems like it's locking in power that could be better spent on more exciting things.  I'd much rather see an interaction with Starcall, such as the following:

Infuse: On enemy cast, doubles the number of Starcall stacks on the target, and then deals damage (her current base + AP scaling for this ability, or maybe something a little lower) and silences for 1/1.25/1.5/1.75/2 seconds + 0.1 second per Starcall stack.  (Alternatively, the damage and silence could be dealt first, and then the Starcall doubling could take effect.)

This introduces a new tradeoff in when to use Infuse; do you use it earlier to accelerate Starcall stacks on the target, or do you use it later to get a stronger direct effect?

Another thing that bugs me about Infuse is that while the dual ally/enemy cast is a great mechanic in theory, in practice by the end of the game (teamfight phase), you will always be saving your Infuse for the silence, because the mana simply isn't worth it by then.  I'd be willing to give up the uniqueness of mana sustain (which admittedly is a very nice, unique early-game benefit) for something similarly unique that is more relevant throughout the game.  Ideas:

Infuse: On ally cast, doubles the number of Starcall stacks (more on this later) on the target, and then reduces the duration of existing CC by 0.5/0.6/0.7/0.8/0.9 second + 0.05 second per Starcall stack

Infuse: On ally cast, doubles the number of Starcall stacks on the target, and then reduces the cooldown of the next spell cast by 5%/6.25%/7.5%/8.75%/10% + 1% per Starcall stack

Speaking of, yes, I think Starcall should be adjusted to affect allies; allies hit by Starcall receive 1/1.5/2/2.5/3 MR per stack (like her old passive); double the mana cost of Starcall, but have it return half of the mana spent if an enemy unit is hit.  This makes it possible but very expensive for her to buff her team before a teamfight, while still preserving her ability to brush check.  I'm guessing for overall power reasons, you might need to remove the cooldown refresh for Astral Blessing, but that's an acceptable tradeoff for more interactions with Infuse.

Is being passive really that bad? I understand it's frustrating to be unable to interact with your opponent without having whatever you just did immediately erased, but I'm not sure the 'welp I got hit by one ability, better hope my flash is up or I'm dead!' that bot lane is right now is much better.
In general having a character that is most successful by being "passive" doesn't promote any real gameplay. Interesting multiplayer gameplay is the result of meaningful interactions between players.

Is 'focus the healer' not gameplay? 'Wait til their heal is on cooldown and then try to burst them down' not good enough? Is there a reason that Janna has gameplay and Soraka doesn't besides 'Janna has to hit the enemy'?

Or am I just reading you wrong?

The main issue with Soraka is during laning phase where she can just top off and hang back under tower. Sure you can be more aggressive when her heal is off CD, but they'll probably play more passive for 10-20 seconds and have heal back up to erase the damage you just tried to apply again.

Unless you're playing a Graves/Annie burst lane it becomes a chore to deal with your lane opponents, which is what Riot is trying to avoid.

"Focus the Healer" really only becomes relevant past lane phase when positioning becomes KEY.
I guess. I'm still not sure why, exactly, that's any worse than the current hyper aggressive 'dodge every hook/zenith blade/binding or you die' meta we have in bot right now, but oh well.
For one, it's a lot easier to change "die in 1 skill shot" to "die in more skill shots" with number tweaks than "never engage because you get nothing out of it" to "engage with the opponent".
That makes sense. It assumes that Riot balancing will, you know, balance things, but at least it makes it possible.

i personally think her w is the real problem her q and e have some interaction. how about making her w to be casted on an enemy and ally but when cast on an enemy it marks and damages them and when an ally's basic hits them it consumes and heals them for a precent of the damage done done to the enemy. this will make u think do we need to play passive and play safe or take a chance and go aggressive

I just had a game where, as Leona/Cait vs. Twitch/Sona, I sat in a lane bush for 20 minutes while Cait and Twitch pounded away at minions under the enemy tower. Twitch would step up and try to hit Cait, Cait would step back and return fire, Sona would heal Twitch, rinse and repeat. For 20 minutes I had to watch this because they were both under their tower (Sona mostly being far enough to be in Fog of War) leaving me no real way to engage. All I could do was ward to make sure we weren't getting ganked and reminisce about the olden days with Garen.

That kind of passivity being an optimal strategy should never be allowed.

Just a question: Have you guys considered to take her E to a different direction, like making it cleanse CC? I mean, if she's intended to be a true healer she should have cleanse CC skills. This would make her a crucial choice for a very agressive lane like Thresh or Leona.

Starcall is a problem then, so how about changing it so it's similar to Luna's Lucent Beam except that it doesn't lock on and has a similar target size as a Maokai Sapling without as much range? Can't think of another example atm.

I don't play Soraka much, but I can say mashing Q nonstop isn't exactly the most engaging thing in the world.

EDIT: I'm not saying just ship that either, if that got changed then I'm sure a slew of other changes would be required. I'm just suggesting a change that might possibly be a step in the right direction.

Starcall, with its short range promotes interactivity, as it forces Soraka to be in the middle of the fight.

On one side, what you suggest, you play with a targeted ground ability from a safe distance, on the other side, what is it right now, you -become- that targeted ground ability, and you have to play with your own position as a catalyst.
The nuance might be subtle, but the current form is imo much more interesting, and even more appealing from a risk reward gameplay, while delivering the same experience.

I would also add, contrary to popular belief, when I play Soraka, I am already quite busy keeping track of everyone on the team, and on the enemy team, their health, their mana, my position, their positions, my R, and I don't need more cluster Q crap to mess with me.
The current starcall does that, as it allows me to focus more on the different aspects of my game.

While your playstle may differ, the dangerously short range of Starcall is exactly why a lot of Soraka don't even level the ability until last. They max Astral Blessing and Infuse, and just sit back.

In it's current iteration Starcall's optimal use is during teamfights to shred the most MR possible while your carries are being focused or peeled for.

Now I do understand not wanting to add a skillshot to Q. I feel Soraka's kit should remain simple. The Soraka player *should* be worried more about positioning, and keeping track of vitals both enemy and ally.

That said the current Q is still a poor choice in a duo lane for the reasons I listed in the thread above, yet is also toxic in a solo lane as pros and streamers have recently begun to highlight. It's unavoidable, shreds MR so each successive hit hits harder, and causes a lot of pressure in the lane as it pushes like no other.

**TL;DR** Perhaps we need to reach some sort of middle ground where Q is more cohesive in a duo lane, but not a skillshot that you have to worry about hitting on top of all your game awareness.

You pretty much always put one point in Q, if not at level 1-3, at level 4, not doing so is a mistake. That's free power.
You don't know what could happen, having some damage for that one fight, or when clearing the tower if your ally had to recall or has been slain etc.

Now you are talking purely from a bottom support marksman passive, farmfest, lane, on summoner's rift, which is only one situation.

I, for one, rarely play these situations, I play random duo lanes with random people, random solo lanes, dominion and aram, and I obviously play with Q all the time.

> That said the current Q is still a poor choice in a duo lane for the reasons I listed in the thread above, yet is also toxic in a solo lane as pros and streamers have recently begun to highlight. It's unavoidable, shreds MR so each successive hit hits harder, and causes a lot of pressure in the lane as it pushes like no other.

It's not different than Garen's spin imo, it simply has bit more range. Yet no one talks about it, ha.
You spin when you have to.

That's good, you're playing Soraka the way Riot would prefer, the way I also enjoy to play her.

I am talking purely from the passive-farmfest view because that's the issue Riot is trying to resolve. While you may play aggressively and allow for a more interactive lane, other Soraka players don't.

Having such a strong heal + mana sustain means the Soraka player has the choice to just sit back and keep his ally healthy. It's the fact that it's an OPTION, and a very safe option at that, that shouldn't exist. Everyone should be playing her more like you do, but they aren't given enough incentive because they don't really appreciate Q's power and rather player her for the dedicated healer archtype.

One thing I would like to maintain is the overall mechanical simplicity of the character. If I can find cool mastery points that doesn't make her targeting paradigms more complex then I would prefer those type of solutions. Not sure if this will be possible, but I think starcall can maintain its auto-target provided that it creates followup gameplay that *does* have interaction.

(This is just me rattling off whatever comes to mind, feel free to ignore me)

Like I mentioned before, I sort of like the idea of an Aggressive Soraka being a more effective Soraka. 

I've wondered about the possibility of Soraka gaining Stacks as she damaged an enemy with Starcall (Which I'd personally like to be turned into a AoE Skillshot, but that's just me), and her heal would consume these stacks to become more powerful. I don't know... I feel like there could still be something better to have, though.

As for her status as a dedicated healer, people have brought up math saying "A lot of champions that have heals can out-heal Soraka in terms of Heal over Time", but I feel like the main thing that makes her a 'dedicated healer' is the ability to grant mana to a teammate: As far as I know, this is an ability that is exclusive to Soraka. I feel like this mana restoring should stay in some fashion if 'Dedicated healer' is to still be a main theme.

I see what you mean about the reduced damage output. (Unrelated note, this is another strong hidden power on Sona's kit that I feel could use some analysis)

I liked my other passive idea, but I was worried it might mean Soraka players might just goto lane, get in some harass and THEN just sit back and let super regeneration do the healing, only using your real heal if things get serious. 

Perhaps we could still go with that regen aura passive if we have the stacks of Astral Blessing fall off over time, giving incentive to keep interacting in lane. Either that or make the regen so weak it feels like goat plop...

Below combines my earlier passive, but with stacks falling off overtime, with the reward system of this thread's setup.

|Ability|Name|Effect|
|-
|(Passive) http://i.imgur.com/2EA0naM.png | Salvation | For every stack of Astral Essence Soraka gains, nearby allies gain an additional 2/5/8 Hp5s and 2/5/8 Mp5s. After 5 seconds a stack of Astral Essence expires. **Max 5 Stacks**|
|(Q) http://i.imgur.com/CJ8Qq6Q.png | Starcall | Calls down an astral being to the target area dealing 60/95/130/165/200 *(+50% Ability Power)*  magic damage. **Soraka gains 1 stack of Astral Essence for every enemy champion hit.**|
|(W) http://i.imgur.com/ALvytBW.png | Astral Blessing | Heals a single ally  for 65/95/125/155/185 (+ 30% AP) and increases their armor by 50/65/80/95/110 *(+15% Ability Power)*. **If Soraka is blessed with Astral Essence, all blessings are consumed and the amount healed is doubled.**|
|(E) http://i.imgur.com/6ADYApR.png | Infuse | On Ally Cast: Soraka drains 5% of her maximum mana to restore 20/40/60/80/100*(+5% maximum mana)* mana to her target ally. **If Soraka is blessed with Astral Essence, all blessings are consumed and the amount restored is doubled.** On Enemy Cast: Soraka silences the target for 1.5/1.75/2/2.25/2.5 seconds and deals 40/70/100/130/160*(+ 40% AP)(+5% maximum mana)* magic damage to them.|

P.S. My goodness, On Ally/Enemy Cast abilities are wordy...

Have you tried any ways in which enemies have the opportunity to counter the heal by attacking in a set amount of time? You could balance that with a mechanic that makes the heal stronger in combat, creating a tension with the soraka player to use the spell in combat, but prevent the enemy from cancelling out the heal...

And if the armour portion was separated from the heal portion, so that the armour came first and the heal was a delayed reaction, how would that affect soraka if a) the strength of the heal was stronger the more damage the armour portion absorbed, b) the heal was weaker the more damage the shield absorbed?

I've been maining Soraka lately. She was my first champion, and I learned to play her passively, but as I've grown as a player I began to learn how to play her **better** (which is to say, NOT entirely passively).

In the same way that you shouldn't use Nami's heal without the damage effect, I've learned that it's best to reserve Astral Blessing until a pivotal moment in a trade, helping your carry to win or helping you to harass better. Doing it poorly is punished because it wastes mana, but doing it well feels very rewarding. Playing Soraka has helped me to understand damage trades, and how to harass with auto-attacks (!) in lane, so much better.

I really love Soraka and I feel that she is very strong without being uncounterable and is actually optimally NOT played passively. If she gets reworked just because people aren't taking advantage of her kit which rewards careful micromanagement of her heal/armor buff, I will be very, very sad.

EDIT: Also, if you do use Astral Blessing merely to keep your carry (or yourself) topped off, you are even more vulnerable to blowing up in all-ins due to its long cooldown...i.e., if I'm Leona and your armor buff just wore off, I'm engaging if at all possible in the next few seconds because I know my carry can do a lot of unmitigated damage.

This might be a bit of a long shot (and sorry if it's been brought up before), but what if you had W heal for a percentage of damage done within the last X seconds.


As an example (using completely arbitrary numbers), your team's J4 jumps into the opponent's team at the start of a teamfight. He takes 1200 damage in 2 seconds and gets hit with a W, healing for 600.

Obviously, the specific numbers would be different, including the "window" that damage can be healed and the percentage that actually gets healed. But Soraka can be kind of the anti-burst who isn't very good at long-term, sustained and passive healing. This version of Soraka would love quick and intense skirmishes and shy away from a slow-paced harassing lane. It gives opponents a strategy to try to limit her effectiveness, and her lane partner incentive to get in there and FIGHT.

Edit: I would give the heal a (low) minimum amount, so that it's not 100% useless outside of fights. Topping someone off after you've aced the enemy team is fine, but we don't want Soraka to just heal for significant life whenever she feels like it.

I think this looks pretty cool. It changes the question from "who to heal?" to "how to heal more?" and in a single-target sort of way. I think that's actually even more in line with the medic archetype.

Some other ways to have healing amp in gameplay might be:

* anti-grievous wound AoE (while standing in this area, champions are healed for more)
* healing amp AoE (while standing in this area, champions heal others for more)
* other application methods of heal stacks
* heal resets or cd reductions (heal cc'd ally -> cd reduction, Astral Blessing on live, etc.)
* ramping healing (like vlad's Tides of Blood stacks)

Also, I'm curious what your previous iteration looked like. Mind posting it?

His previous iteration had her passive giving her increased regen to allies as Soraka casted. Regen auras aren't really appreciable either, but the idea of selfish team power over negating enemy power was sound. 

Another approach is just to allow Soraka herself to scale up by saying something like "every spell that hits a champion grants Soraka X bonus AP for Y seconds, this buff stacks up to Z times."

Then both her heals and damage become more threatening in a way the Soraka player can personally appreciate. This is more of a tank pattern, but I could see a world in which Soraka has a passive similar to this.

> Healing is negative damage, so the same mechanics that mitigate the negative effects of burst damage can also be applied to healing.

Is this a valid way to look at heals? So like could there be a distinction between "fighter-healer" who scales up over drawn out fights and "burst-healer" who turns a fight in a quicker moment? Of course, the current health bar UI doesn't communicate regen in a satisfying way, so that's a much harder archetype to fill.

I guess what I'm getting at is that if I were to try to build Soraka without scaling her healing abilities, I'd want to build her as a tank, where as someone like Sona or Nami would be more a mage build. Does that even make any sense?

In both cases, the real question to ask is "where can we get gameplay out of heals?" Both a sustained healer and a burst healer fill different functions, but what we really need is a way to give heals gameplay. Soraka's current W does this to some degree because it grants massive amounts of armor which is only useful in combat but also causes the enemy to re-evaluate their targeting decisions. Unfortunately, for the armor to be powerful enough to matter, we had to take away raw healing power. I believe that players who want to play the healer character probably want big heals. The problem I'm solving now is how to give them the big heal moments in a way that causes interaction with the enemy.

How about empowering the heal if it's used after landing starcall on an enemy champion? That way you get way less efficiency if it's just used passively to top off or recover after near-death, and more if Soraka puts herself at risk.

It can also be made even more interesting if the heal gets empowered -for each time- starcall is used on enemy champions before it is cast, making it more potent if it is cast as late as possible (not counting the current armor bonus). This would also have the added effect of making the strength of the heal scale indirectly with cdr.

That might be too complex/pattern changing though.

What if you just reversed the armor buff idea?  So, instead of a small heal and a significant armor buff, Soraka's heal granted a lot more health but also gave her teammates an armor/mr debuff for a short amount of time (possibly 2-3 seconds).

I know you're trying to avoid making Soraka a "top them off" type of healer who prefers to between fights rather than during them, but consider it this way: heal spells will be used to top off champions in between fights regardless of how you change them.  By giving it a short debuff, it allows the enemy team to react to the spell correctly and try to eliminate the effects of a heal.  It also means that a Soraka player has to be very careful while selecting her targets DURING fights, because picking the wrong target could get your teammate killed.  

It may seem like this would encourage passive play during team fights, but without her heal Soraka is almost irrelevant in team fights.  Soraka would eventually have to make the decision to try to heal someone to keep them alive in a fight or just be a useless champion.  This also would act to provide some counterplay to the current poke-heavy meta and encourage the enemy team to dive in.

Furthermore, if you worry about putting a debuff on a team-targeted spell, what if you put an mr/armor buff that negates the debuff onto her E.  This creates more of a decision for Soraka players during team fights: do I want to heal and then protect (while giving mana to) a single teammate, or do I want to heal and then silence an enemy to prevent them from using a powerful spell?

Maybe not a perfect idea, but I think it creates counter play while simultaneously allowing Soraka to be a dedicated healer type of champ and shifting some power away from her currently freakish team-fighting ability and back into laning phase.
The idea of an ability that debuffs an ally sounds rather toxic. I can see that being an issue with trolls. It also punishes the ally for the support's poor decision rather directly.

I can definitely see trolls being an issue.  I just think it provides the enemy team with a window of opportunity to say "There's a heal, go now!"  So now instead of seeing a heal and immediately backing off, the enemy team/lane has to weigh their options and make a quick decision on whether or not its beneficial to go in.  

Definitely a backwards concept, but one that would encourage the enemy team to interact, rather than trying to keep away and powerfarm the lane.

//

So I've thought this idea out a little longer and I think it would look a something a little like this:

Q and R remain the same.

W heals for x amount and also decreases armor or mr by .1x for 2-3 seconds (Numbers are arbitrary, just an idea)

E functions as it does currently while also granting .1x armor/mr to allies


Casting W now gives the enemy team an opportunity it jump in and take advantage for a small amount of time.

When the enemy team does jump in, E either removes the debuff and provides enough extra mana for an ally to use an escape or it silences a high damage/high cc enemy to give your ally a longer time to get away.  

Now you have decisions to make as Soraka:  Do you heal an ally while E is on cooldown?  Do you silence an enemy or buff an ally and hope they can escape by themself?

The debuff on W isn't large/long enough to outright kill a teammate but does give a small power spike to enemies who are aware enough to take advantage of it (not everyone will be)

Furthermore, Soraka becomes more of a "dedicated" healer.  W is no longer a cast and forget type of spell.  You have to spend 2-3 more seconds focused on (dedicated to, if you will) that ally to make sure they escape the fight with their life.

As for trolls, there isn't really much you can do about them.  However, they will be in the game regardless of the circumstances and usually find a way to screw over their own team.  Trundle and Anivia both have spells that could be used to troll their own teams but they aren't really ever used that way.

tl dr:  An ally debuff is weird but may create the counter play to a strong heal spell

I have some problems with the idea of stacking mechanics, such as the suggestions several people have mentioned in this thread. My biggest concern is that they encourage Soraka to do other things BEFORE she heals, reducing her ability to react to unexpected situations (especially before level 6). Mitigating unexpected damage is (I think) an important aspect of the dedicated healer fantasy (and one of the things that makes healing unique from shields), and for that you need a large degree of control over where you put your heal, and when. It needs to be something you decide based on who needs healing, and when they need it the most, and I think it needs to be there when you click, if at all possible.

Another problem is that stacking encourages longer periods of engagement, which is more than what’s necessary to fix the non-interaction problem in lane. Plenty of champions interact in lane by poking and attempting to avoid retaliation. Also, it sounds like the resistance shred from Starcall already seems to provide plenty of incentive for sustained combat in teamfights. If possible, I think it would be best to leave the stacking mechanic for beefier supports (Alistar seems like a very good candidate).

One possible idea is a sort of martyrdom mechanic, but not in the way that was described earlier in the thread. It would go something like this (but with better names):

Passive: Hitting enemy champions grants Soraka a stack of [Astral Payment], up to a maximum of 2(3?). Any stack of [Astral Price] gained will cancel out one stack of [Astral Payment], removing each other.

Astral Blessing: Heals an allied champion for [much healz], but places 2(3?) stacks of [Astral Price]. If any stacks of [Astral Price] remain on Soraka after [not many] seconds, Soraka loses [ouch*] health for each stack, and all stacks are removed. Any stack of [Astral Payment] gained will cancel out one stack of [Astral Price], removing each other.   *The health loss might be best as a percentage of max hp, to prevent any trivialization through hp itemization.

Note: This mechanic would happen instead of the armor buff, with more power going into the actual heal. I’m not sure how self-heals should be tuned. Also, I allowed the stacks to proc on any hits instead of just Starcall. In its current state, the low cooldown on Starcall makes it no big deal to force the player to use it in close proximity to Astral Blessing, but if Starcall changes into something with a longer cooldown (or unreliable application), then you run into the same problems I was bemoaning earlier in my comment. Soraka would have to consider the availability of Starcall before deciding whether her ally (who is about to die!) should get a heal.

One advantage to this setup is that it would force Soraka to expose herself to enemy harassment one way or another. If tuned properly, avoiding the enemies in lane will hurt just as much as engaging them, without the corresponding benefits. It also gives the opponent some of their satisfaction back when she chooses to heal from safety, because they can see that their attacks are making it to her health bar, even if the path they take to get there is a little longer. Another advantage is that, in situations where there are too many enemies to approach safely , such as a soured teamfight or a jungler gank, Soraka can still deliver her full heal, and pay a more manageable cost than getting her face ripped off. This also lumps all of the spell’s healing into one point of application, allowing the player to focus on who needs healing, and when, and having that healing available on demand. This just might allow Soraka to fulfill the dedicated healer fantasy without forcing her lane opponents to go make a sandwich and come back later. 
Continued….

One big problem with my setup is that an opponent with on-demand crowd control can prevent Soraka from avoiding the damage after her heal. This would be fine, except that it gives the Soraka player no incentive to approach them, lest she eat harassment damage on top of her own stacks. I suppose the stacks could be removed upon enemy crowd control, but that would make for less counter-play to a kit that already has a lot of inevitability. Another problem with this idea is that it doesn’t do anything about mid-lane Soraka (though that might be more about changing Starcall).

A less adventurous version of this mechanic would be wrap up some of the heal into 2(3?) extra heal procs on Soraka’s target from stacks of [Astral Payment] (both pre-existing stacks and those gained during the few seconds after the heal, up to the same cap) instead of the health-loss mechanic. This loses some of the satisfaction of the on-demand heal, and it would probably need to be tuned down more to prevent passive play (such that the heal would be too weak or too inefficient to sustain without empowering it through combat). On the upside, it probably has a lot less potential for unforeseen gameplay problems.

I think there are ways that this mechanic could interact with her other abilities as well, but this post is already too long.
